2: place of considerable size and strength for the times in which it was built
3:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  On the south-west the outer wall or enceinte is entered by a rude gateway of a single pointed arch about eight feet high and five feet broad.

Triplets:<Varugad
5:
--------------------
<Text: Varugad:  The gate lies about 150 yards east of the edge of the plateau, which there terminates in an almost unbroken vertical precipice of several hundred feet in height and receding in a north-easterly direction.>
Triplets:<Varugad
9:
--------------------
<Text: Varugad:  Facing nearly north, about fifty yards from the north-east angle, is a gateway with a couple of curtains in solid masonry.>
Triplets:<Varugad
12:
--------------------
<Text: Varugad:  It leads out to the path down to Girvi, a village in the plains below and it probably formed the communication with Phaltan.>
Triplets:<Varugad
13:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  This road winds down the face of the range for some five hundred feet till it hits the shoulder of a spur which it then follows to the base.
Triplets:<Varugad
14:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The walling on the south side, from the edge of the cliff to some hundred yards east of the southern gate, is not more than a couple of feet in thickness and consists of all-fitting stones unmortared.

Triplets:<Varugad
16:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The average height is from seven to ten feet.
Triplets:<Varugad
18:
--------------------
<Text: Varugad:  On the right side of the southern gate is a well preserved stone pond about thirty yards square with steps leading down to it.>
Triplets:<Varugad
19:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  Next to and on the north of Bhairavnath's temple is another pond.

Triplets:<Varugad
20:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The way up to the fort proper or upper and lower citadels is from the north side.
Triplets:<Varugad
21:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The path up the hill side, which is steep but with grass and soil left in Man y places, is almost destroyed.
Triplets:<Varugad
25:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  Its entrance lies close below that to the upper citadel.
Triplets:<Varugad
27:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  On the south side the walls are carried right up to the scarp of the upper citadel and are some ten feet high, so that to take the lower citadel in rear or flank must have been difficult.
Triplets:<Varugad
29:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The entrance to it lies some thirty feet above that to the lower citadel, and is cut in the rock about eight feet wide.

Triplets:<Varugad
30:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  There is a gateway of a pointed arch with the top fallen in and twenty odd steps leading up to it and ten more cut out of the rock, and winding up past the inside curtain on to the top.
Triplets:<Varugad
31:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The walls of this upper citadel are still in tolerable preservation.

are still in tolerable preservation>

Text: Varugad:  There is a large turret on the south-west corner, evidently meant to comMan d the southern gate.

Text: Varugad:  Next to it on the south is a small pond evenly cut and lined with mortar used for storing water.

<Text: Varugad:  The outer walls east of the gates have bastions at every turn of the cliffs, and the masonry here is particularly strong and well preserved.>

<Text: Varugad:  After passing the southern gateway the assailants would be commanded Maan, Maharashtra from the lower citadel.>

45:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  The appearance from the fort of the plain in the north is most formidable.
Triplets:<Varugad
49:
--------------------
<Text: Varugad:  The fort garrison consisted of 200 Ramoshis, Mahars, and other hereditary Gadkaris besides sepoys.>
Triplets:<Varugad
50:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  It was surrendered in 1818 to Vitthal Pant Phadnis of the Raja of Satara left in charge of the town.
Triplets:<Varugad
51:
--------------------
Text: Varugad:  He detached 200 men to take possession, being part of a force then raised to protect the town from the enterprizes of Bajirav's garrisons then in the neighbourhood.
